doc.headline: Are we to blame for Bangladesh factory collapse?
doc.post:
Seems the factory supplied companies like Primark and the Spanish firm Mango. Is it the companies fault for not demanding safer working conditions in their suppliers. Or is it our fault for choosing the cheaper option when we purchase?
http://www.guardian.co.uk/world/2013...rk-inspections

It has everything to do with the fact that loads of factories in China, India etc, are unsafe anyway, and have multiple factories crammed into a single multistorey buildings.
Although Primark etc do make money by using these sweatshops, the local businessmen also make money and they don´t seem to care about the safety aspect of the local workers when considering their profits.
Surely as the workers were not employed by Primark, then the employer (probably local) should be held responsible, because even if there was no Primark contract the building would still have been used to make cheap clothing for another company.
Its the Builders who should be blamed..not the factory owners..

Its the Builders who should be blamed..not the factory owners..
......and the govt for not exercising proper building regulations.
I wouldn't imagine for one moment that those responsible for controlling building standards would ever dream of turning a blind eye to a little corner cutting in return for the odd back hander.

in answer to the basic question NO!!
if you start taking personal responsibility for everything at all subcontractors, suppliers etc then you will drive yourself into an early grave.
being a shareholder in the company you buy from may give you some different "responsibilities" but until then...........
keep buying, there are others who will be looking over the shoulders of those who are cutting corners.
